G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Complaint for Modification is brought pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and other applicable authorities.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28 and 30.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this Complaint pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 30, as the parties and the minor child reside in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

*Prenaveau v. Prenaveau*, 81 Mass. App..proposition: A modification to a prior custody order is appropriate when a material and substantial change in circumstances has occurred since the issuance of the order. *Prenaveau v. Prenaveau*, 81 Mass. App. Ct. 479, 486 (2012).
*Prenaveau v. Prenaveau*, 81 Mass. App..support_reasoning: This opinion is about relocation/removal and custody, but it is not a modification case framed around the standard of a "material and substantial change in circumstances" since a prior custody order. The court discusses best interests, continuity, removal standards under G.L. c. 208, § 30, and abuse of discretion, but does not articulate or apply a material-change requirement as the governing test for modifying an earlier custody judgment. Citing this case for that specific proposition overstates what it holds.
*Prenaveau v. Prenaveau*, 81 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “Analysis. 1. Standard of review for custody determination. The amended judgment relocating the children from Massachusetts to New Hampshire must comply with the provision of G. L. c. 208, § 30, prohibiting the unconsented-to removal of minor children… except by court order ‘upon cause shown.’ … ‘Cause shown’ requires removal to serve the best interests of the child. … The appellate court reviews the trial judge’s determination of a child’s best interests for clear error of fact finding and abuse of discretion.”

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The evidence of the Defendant’s alleged alcohol consumption during parenting time constitutes a material and substantial change in circumstances impacting Michael’s safety. See *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 261 (2001) (noting the court’s authority to restrict parenting time to safeguard a child’s welfare).
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The case concerns standards for modifying custody and permitting removal from the Commonwealth; it does not address parental alcohol use, material changes based on substance abuse, or specific safety concerns like those in the proposed proposition. While the opinion discusses the court’s general authority to modify or restrict custody in the child’s best interests, it is not about imposing restrictions on parenting time due to alcohol consumption or any comparable safety-based change. Using this case to support that specific alcohol-related proposition overstates and mischaracterizes its holding.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “A judgment modifying custody must be based on findings grounded in the evidence that, since the date of the prior custody order, there has been a change in circumstances ‘of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle by which the court must be guided in these cases, namely, whether the transfer of custody will be conducive to the welfare of the [child].’ Fuller v. Fuller, 2 Mass. App. Ct. 372, 376 (1974). ‘The uprooting of a child . . . should be done only for compelling reasons.’”

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (20.proposition: The Court has consistently emphasized that the child’s safety and well-being are paramount when crafting or modifying custody orders. See *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (2012); *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 404 (1981).
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (20.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely discusses the standard for custody determinations and emphasizes that the “touchstone” is the child’s best interests, evaluated through factors tied to the child’s physical, mental, and emotional well-being. The court further affirms that custody must be based on which parent can best meet the child’s needs, including stability and avoidance of harm, rather than on punishing parental misconduct. This aligns with the proposition that the child’s safety and well-being are paramount when crafting or modifying custody orders.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (20.relevant_excerpt: “Parents have an equal right to custody of their children. … ‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] … what is ‘best for the child’….’ … The judge shall consider ‘whether or not the child’s present or past living conditions adversely affect his physical, mental, moral or emotional health.’ G. L. c. 208, § 31. Factors a judge may weigh are whether one parent’s home is more stable in terms of a parent’s work schedule, whether siblings are being raised together, and whether one parent seeks to undermine the relationship a child has with the other parent.”

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.proposition: The Court has consistently emphasized that the child’s safety and well-being are paramount when crafting or modifying custody orders. See *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (2012); *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 404 (1981).
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.support_reasoning: The opinion directly states that in custody determinations the court’s overriding concern must be the children’s best interests, happiness, and welfare, and applies that standard to uphold the custody and visitation orders. The court emphasizes that the ‘best interests’ principle focuses on the child’s welfare, even when it limits a parent’s liberties, which aligns with the proposition that the child’s safety and well-being are paramount in crafting or modifying custody orders.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare. … As a corollary to this standard… ‘the happiness and the welfare of the children] should be the controlling consideration.’… The ‘best interests’ principle requires that the narrow focus be on the interests of the child.… ‘[T]he ‘best interests’ of the child[ren] are to be promoted, and when the parents are at odds [as here], the attainment of that purpose may involve some limitation of the liberties of one or other of the parents.’”

*C.P. v. J.M.* 52 Mass. App. Ct. 805, 81.proposition: The Court has the authority to order supervised parenting time or otherwise impose restrictions when there are legitimate concerns about a parent’s ability to provide a safe environment. See *C.P. v. J.M.* 52 Mass. App. Ct. 805, 810-11 (2001).
*C.P. v. J.M.* 52 Mass. App. Ct. 805, 81.case_name: Boston Towing & Transportation Co. v. Commissioner of Revenue
*C.P. v. J.M.* 52 Mass. App. Ct. 805, 81.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is a Massachusetts tax case involving sales and use taxes on commercial boats and does not concern family law, custody, or parenting time. It does not discuss supervised parenting time, parental fitness, or court authority to impose restrictions for child safety. The citation to C.P. v. J.M. for that proposition is therefore inaccurate in the context of this text, which appears to be from a completely different case (a tax decision, not a custody/parenting case).
*C.P. v. J.M.* 52 Mass. App. Ct. 805, 81.relevant_excerpt: “The taxpayers, Boston Towing and Transportation Co. (Boston Towing) and Crosby Tow Boat, Inc. (Crosby), appeal from decisions of the Appellate Tax Board (board) upholding the Commissioner of Revenue’s (commissioner’s) imposition of excise taxes for use of their boats in the Commonwealth… We affirm.”
